questions.text: Copper is deposited in which of the following structures Wilson's disease:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Descemet's membrane Kayser-Fleischer rings are formed by the deposition of copper in the Descemet membrane in the limbus of the cornea. The color may range from greenish gold to brown; when well developed, rings may be readily visible to the naked eye or with an ophthalmoscope set at +40. The rings may be identified using slit-lamp examination or gonioscopy when not visible to the unaided eye.

Highyeild:

Kayser-Fleischer rings are formed by the deposition of copper in the Descemet membrane in the limbus of the cornea. The color may range from greenish gold to brown; when well developed, rings may be readily visible to the naked eye or with an ophthalmoscope set at +40. The rings may be identified using slit-lamp examination or gonioscopy when not visible to the unaided eye. Kayser-Fleischer rings are observed in up to 90% of individuals with symptomatic Wilson disease and are almost invariably present in those with neurologic manifestations. Although Kayser-Fleischer rings are a useful diagnostic sign, they are no longer considered pathognomonic of Wilson's disease unless accompanied by neurologic manifestations. They may also be observed in patients with chronic cholestatic disorders, such as partial biliary atresia, primary biliary cirrhosis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and cryptogenic cirrhosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Epithelium: Crystalline keratopathy is a condition in which crystals are deposited in the corneal epithelium and/or anterior stroma. The Hudson–Stahli line is a line of iron deposition lying roughly on the border between the middle and lower thirds of the cornea. It lies in the corneal epithelium. Option: B. Endothelium: Cellular deposits on the corneal endothelium. Acute, fresh KPs are white and round, while old KPs are usually irregular, faded, and pigmented. Option: C. Stroma: Crystalline keratopathy is a condition in which crystals are deposited in the corneal epithelium and/or anterior stroma.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child with Down’s syndrome presents with a 14 mm horizontal diameter of the cornea. The cornea is clear with normal vision. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Megalocornea The given case history points towards the diagnosis of Megalocornea . Megalocornea is labelled when the horizontal diameter of the cornea is of adult size at birth or 13 mm or greater after the age of 2 years.

Extraedge:

Anomalies of Size and Shape: Cornea Megalocornea Definition: Horizontal diameter of the cornea at birth is about 10 mm, and the adult size of about 11.7 mm is attained by the age of 2 years. Megalocornea is labeled when the horizontal diameter of the cornea is of adult size at birth or 13 mm or greater after the age of 2 years. Salient Features : The cornea is usually clear with normal thickness and vision. The condition is not progressive. Systemic associations include Marfan's, Alport, Ehlers-Danlos, and Down syndromes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the microscopic structure of the cornea is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: E is also known as posterior elastic lamina

options.label: B
options.text: Unlike B, layer E can regenerate.

options.label: C
options.text: B is a true elastic membrane

options.label: D
options.text: C consists of collagen fibrils (type-I and type-V fibrillae)

questions.correct_answer: C. B is a true elastic membrane
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B is a true elastic membrane It is not a true elastic membrane but simply a condensed superficial part of the stroma. A- Epithelium B- Bowman’s membrane C- Stroma (substantia propria) D- Pre–Descemet’s membrane aka Dua’s layer E- Descemet’s membrane (posterior elastic lamina). F- Endothelium

Highyeild:

Bowman’s membrane: This layer consists of a cellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. It is about 12 mm in thickness and binds the corneal stroma anteriorly with the epithelium's basement membrane. It is not a true elastic membrane but simply a condensed superficial part of the stroma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Descemet's membrane is also known as posterior elastic Lamina. The Descemet's membrane is a strong homogenous basement membrane of the corneal endothelium, which is separated from the stroma by the pre-Descemet's membrane. Option: B. Unlike Bowman's membrane, Descemet's membrane can regenerate. Normally, it remains in a state of tension, and when torn , it curls inwards on itself. Option: D. It consists of collagen fibrils (type-I and type-V fibrillae intertwined with filaments of type-VI collagen) embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans (chondroitin sulphate and keratan sulphate). The lamellae are arranged in many layers. In each layer they are parallel to each other and the corneal plane and become continuous with sclera lamellae at the limbus.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with an 8 mm corneal horizontal diameter. The cornea has been comparatively flat since birth. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cornea plana The given case history and findings point towards diagnosing cornea plana. This is a rare anomaly in which the bilateral cornea has been flat since birth. It may be associated with microcornea . Cornea plana usually result in marked astigmatic refractive error.

Highyeild:

Microcornea : In microcornea, the horizontal diameter is less than 10 mm since birth. The condition may occur as an isolated anomaly (rarely) or in association with nanophthalmos (normal small eyeball) or microphthalmos (abnormal small eyeball). Cornea plana This is a rare anomaly in which the bilateral cornea is comparatively flat since birth. It may be associated with microcornea. Cornea plana usually result in marked astigmatic refractive error.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Normal small eyeball is called nanophthalmos. It may occur in association with microcornea. In microcornea, the horizontal diameter is less than 10 mm since birth. Option: C. Sclerocornea refers to a sclera-like cloudy cornea , which may be peripheral or diffuse. Option: D. Anterior embryotoxon is characterized by congenitally broad limbus superiorly. Posterior embryotoxon refers to Schwalbe's line's thickening and anterior displacement.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are not correct about the structure of the cornea?

options.label: A
options.text: The sources of nutrition of the cornea are the vessels of the limbus, the aqueous, and the tears.

options.label: B
options.text: The space between the back of the cornea and the front of the iris is called the posterior chamber

options.label: C
options.text: The Descemet’s membrane, constituting the basal lamina of the corneal endothelium, has a homogeneous appearance on light microscopy but a laminated appearance on electron microscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Failure of endothelial function leads to corneal edema

questions.correct_answer: B. The space between the back of the cornea and the front of the iris is called the posterior chamber
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The space between the back of the cornea and the front of the iris is called the posterior chamber The space between the back of the cornea and the front of the iris is called the anterior chamber and normally has aqueous that supplies nutrition to the cornea. The periphery of the anterior chamber is called the angle of the anterior chamber; its width depends upon the contour of the iris and the depth of the anterior chamber

Highyeild:

Blood supply: Cornea is an avascular structure . Small loops derived from the anterior ciliary vessels invade its periphery for about I mm. Actually, these loops are not in the cornea but in the subconjunctival tissue, which overlaps the cornea.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: The sources of nutrition of the cornea are the vessels of the limbus, the aqueous, and tears. The superficial cornea also gets most of its oxygen from the atmosphere directly. Option: C. The Descemet's membrane, constituting the basal lamina of the corneal endothelium, has a homogeneous appearance on light microscopy but a laminated appearance on electron microscopy because of structural differences between its prenatal and postnatal portions. It is about three μm thick at birth but increases in thickness throughout life, reaching 10-12 μm in adulthood. Option: D. The endothelium is quite susceptible to injury and undergoes a loss of cells with age, the normal density reducing from 23,000 cells/mm2 at birth to 2000 cells/mm2 in old age. Endothelial repair is limited to the enlargement of existing cells with little capacity for cell division. Failure of endothelial function leads to corneal edema.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was given a drug to decrease the intraocular pressure in open-angle glaucoma. After a few months, the patient presents with the following eye finding with not much visual abnormalities. Which of the following is true about the condition ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Caused by netarsudil; reversible The given image is of corneal verticillata. It is a bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of cream-colored lines. It is usually mild, reversible on withdrawal of the drug, and not associated with significant visual abnormalities. Netarsudil is a rho kinase inhibitor. It reduced IOP by increasing aqueous outflow through trabecular meshwork by relaxing it.

Highyeild:

This is a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium seen in patients on long-term treatment with medications such as amiodarone, chloroquine, phenothiazines, and indomethacin . It is also seen in patients with Fabry disease and its carrier state. The whorl-like pattern shows the direction of migration of corneal epithelial cells. Occasionally, the condition had been known to cause glare and surface discomfort, which responds to topical lubricants. The condition is generally asymptomatic, harmless, and reversible on stopping the drug.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A and C. Apraclonidine does not cause corneal verticillata Option: D. It is a reversible process.

Extraedge:

Other Causes of Corneal Verticillata : Fabry’s disease Amiodarone Chloroquine & hydroxychloroquine Indomethacin Phenothiazine

questions.text: Match the corneal opacities to their respective characteristics from the options given in the table. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-4, b-3, c-1, d-2. A. Nebula or a nebular corneal opacity : If the corneal scar results in slight opacification, allowing the details of the iris to be seen through the opacity. B. Macula or a macular corneal opacity : If rather more dense, through which the details of the iris cannot be seen, but the iris and pupillary margins are visible. C. Leucoma or a leucomatous corneal opacity : If very dense and white and opaque, obscuring the view of the iris and the pupil. D. Corneo Iridic scar : If iris tissue is incarcerated and incorporated within the scar tissue, as occurs in the healing of a large sloughed corneal ulcer, it is called a Corneo-Iridic scar or, if ectatic, an anterior staphyloma.

Highyeild:

Types of corneal opacity Depending on the density, corneal opacity is graded as nebula, macula, and leucoma . Nebular corneal opacity . It is a faint opacity that results due to superficial scars involving Bowman's layer and superficial stroma. A thin, diffuse nebula covering the pupillary area interferes more with vision than the localized leu coma away from the pupillary area. Further, the nebula produces more discomfort to patients due to blurred images owing to irregular astigmatism than the leucoma, which completely curbs the light rays. Macular corneal opacity . It is a semi-dense opacity produced when scarring involves about half the corneal stroma. Leucomatous corneal opacity (leucoma simplex) . It is a dense white opacity that results due to scarring of more than half of the stroma. Adherent leucoma. It results when healing occurs after the perforation of the cornea with the incarceration of the iris. Corneal facet . Sometimes, the corneal surface is depressed at the healing site (due to less fibrous tissue); such a scar is called a facet. Kerectasia . In this condition, corneal curvature is increased at the site of opacity (bulge due to weak scar). Anterior staphyloma . An ectasia of pseudocornea (the scar formed from organised exudates and fibrous tissue covered with epithelium) which results after total sloughing of the cornea, with the iris plastered behind it, is called anterior staphyloma.

questions.text: An image showing fluorescein staining in a patient with itching and watering is given below. Which of the following statements are correct about this defect It is viewed with cobalt green filtered light If superficial without any inflammation, it heals within 12–24 hours If it presents with a yellowish hazy appearance it is termed as infiltration. Loss of epithelium without surrounding inflammation leads to ulcer Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

b and c only The given Image shows a corneal epithelial defect stained with fluorescein. Loss/damage to the epithelium is termed an epithelial defect.

Highyeild:

Epithelium: It is the outermost layer of the cornea and is composed of stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelial cells. It becomes continuous with the epithelium of the bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, the next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells, and the most superficial two layers are made of flattened cells . Bowman's membrane . This layer consists of an acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils Stroma (substantia propria). This layer is about 0.5 mm in thickness and constitutes most of the cornea (90% of the total thickness). It consists of collagen fibrils (type-I and type-V fibrillae intertwined with filaments of type-VI collagen) embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans (chondroitin sulphate and keratan sulphate) Pre- Descemet's membrane, also known as Dua's layer , was discovered in 2013 by Dr. Harminder Dua, an Indian ophthalmologist working in Great Britain. Located anterior to the Descemec's membrane, it is about 15 micrometer thick acellular structure that is very strong and impervious to air. Descemet's membrane (posterior elastic lamina) . The Descemet's membrane is a strong homogenous basement membrane of the corneal endothelium, which is separated from the stroma by the pre-Descemet's membrane. Endothelium . It consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) epithelial cells (misnamed as the endothelium) which on slit-lamp biomicroscopy, appear as a mosaic.

Random:

Explanation for all options: - Option: A. It can be demonstrated clearly by staining with 1 percent sodium fluorescein dye and viewed with cobalt blue filter light. Option: B. If superficial without any inflammation, an epithelial defect is also called an abrasion or erosion and usually heals within 12-24 hours by regeneration of the epithelial cells from the periphery, which slide over to cover the defect. Option: C. Inflammation in the cornea is visible as a greyish haze or loss of clarity. If accompanied by an outpouring of leucocytes, the appearance is more off-white or yellowish, and this hazy area as termed as an infiltration. Option: D. A loss of epithelium with inflammation in the surrounding cornea is called a corneal ulcer. Corneal ulcers can be infective or sterile.

questions.text: The cornea is the most important refractive surface of the eye and allows the transmission of light through its transparency. Which of the following factors do not contribute to its transparency?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a relatively hydrated state

options.label: C
options.text: Uniform spacing of the collagen fibrils

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a relatively hydrated state
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a relatively hydrated state The transparency of the cornea is due to its relatively dehydrated state . This relative state of dehydration is maintained by the integrity of the hydrophobic epithelium and endothelium, the endothelial pump, and the osmotic gradient because the aqueous and tears are relatively hypertonic. The main role of the endothelial cells is to limit the fluid intake of the cornea from the aqueous.

Highyeild:

“Corneal transparency” The corneal transparency is the result of: Anatomical factors such as: Corneal epithelium and tear film. Homogeneity of the refractive index throughout the epithelium. Peculiar arrangement of corneal lamellae (lattice theory of Maurice). Peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae with variation less than 200 µm (Goldmann and Benedek theory). Avascularity of the cornea. Physiological factors keep the cornea in a relative state of dehydration (78% water content). These factors are: Barrier function of limiting layers (epithelium and endothelium). Endothelial pumps . The corneal endothelium is predominant in controlling fluid transport due to several enzyme systems: Na/K ATPase pump, Bicarbonate-dependent ATPase, and Na-H' pump, and is thus the most important factor in maintaining corneal dehydration. Evaporation from the corneal surface . Normal intraocular pressure (IOP) . Swelling pressure (SP) of the stroma counters the imbibition effect of intraocular pressure (IOP). Corneal crystallins , i.e., waler soluble proteins of keratocytes (transketolase and aldehyde dehydrogenase class lAl) also contribute to corneal transparency at the cellular level

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Uniform refractive index of all the layers is essential to maintain transparency of the cornea. Option: C. Uniform spacing of the collagen fibrils in the stroma: The collagen fibrils are separated by a distance that is less than the wavelength of light so that any irregularly refracted rays of light are eliminated by destructive interference. And thus, this is lattice formation. If there is an increase in separation of the stromal collagen or a disruption in their regular arrangement, such as an increase in tissue fluid, the cornea becomes opaque. Option: D. Absence of blood vessels and pigment is essential to maintain transparency of the cornea.

questions.text: Below is an image of enlarged corneal nerves that were incidentally detected during an annual checkup for a 40-year-old male. He doesn’t have any other complaints. Which one of the following is not associated with this case?
questions.correct_answer: D. Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN), type I
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN), type I Prominent or enlarged corneal nerves may be asymptomatic and detected accidentally or may be associated with other local disease conditions such as keratoconus. The corneal nerves are known to be enlarged in the multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome type IIb (combination of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas and possibly Marfanoid habitus). MEN, type IIb ( Sipple-Gorlin syndrome), is associated with enlarged corneal nerves, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A & C. Other systemic diseases associated with prominent corneal nerves include neurofibromatosis, ichthyosis, and Refsum syndrome. Option B. Local ocular disorders with this clinical sign include keratoconus, keratitis (most characteristically seen in acanthamoeba keratitis ), Fuchs endothelial dystrophy, trauma, and congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: Sham was playing cricket with his friends. He was hit with a ball during the play. The result of his Placido disc test is shown below. What is the correct interpretation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Irregularities of corneal surface The given image is of Placido's keratoscope disc . It is a disc painted with alternating black and white circles. It may be used to assess the smoothness and curvature of the corneal surface.

Placido's keratoscope disc . It is a disc painted with alternating black and white circles. It may be used to assess the smoothness and curvature of the corneal surface. questions.text: A 28-year-old male involved in a traffic accident was referred to the ophthalmology department for further evaluation. Which one of the following would best be used to identify a corneal wound leak? Gentian violet Rose bengal Fluorescein Lissamine green Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C only Concentrated fluorescein, when applied to the corneal wound and viewed with a blue filter, appears dark black. If there is a corneal wound leak, the aqueous will dilute the fluorescein revealing a trail glowing yellow. This can be helpful even for pinpoint leaks . The rapidity of the dilution is representative of the size of the leak.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Gentian violet: Gentian violet is an antiseptic dye used to treat fungal skin infections (such as ringworm and athlete's foot). Option: B. Rose Bengal: Rose Bengal stain is taken up wherever there is a deficiency of preocular tear film protection, thereby helping diagnose ocular surface disorders . Option: D . Lissamine green: High affinity for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands.
